benchmark_details.name: BouncerBench
benchmark_details.overview: BouncerBench is a benchmark that evaluates whether LLM-based software agents can refuse to act when inputs are ill-defined or when their own outputs are likely to be incorrect.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The primary objective of BouncerBench is to evaluate the capability of LLM-based agents to abstain from acting on underspecified inputs or incorrect outputs while promoting research in improving their reliability.

data.source: SWE-Bench Verified dataset, human-annotated for vagueness and correctness.
data.size: 46,238 LLM-generated patches evaluated across 1,699 input tasks and 642 output tasks.
data.annotation: Annotated by 93 software developers experienced in Python.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on binary classifications of actions as bounce or process, with adjustments for ambiguity and correctness.
methodology.interpretation: Higher scores indicate better performance in correctly identifying when to abstain or reject incorrect outputs.
methodology.baseline_results: O4-mini achieved a macro-F measure of 0.592 for input bouncing; Codex achieved a macro-F measure of 0.690 for output bouncing.
